fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I am a PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory.
\mu HOL^{ex} is a logic and cyclic proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
This website uses the Forester tool developed by Jon Sterling. See Jon's website for tutorials/information about the tool.
It is a fantastic way to organise notes and I've been enjoying it a lot! There is even a VSCode plugin.

fr:title.text: Formalisation of unfolding, weakening and substitution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formalisation of unfolding, weakening and substitution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: After submitting the "Distributive Laws of Monadic Containers" paper, Reuben and I caught up with the current state of the \mu HOL^{ex} work.
I am going to attempt to formalise the intution we developed in the above meeting. First, we need to (re)state key definitions.

A cycle (f , \theta ) satisfies bud freshness when:
f is a bijection
the (non-identity part of the) domain and image of \theta are disjoint
A cycle (f , \theta ) is label-cyclic when, if we consider the set V := \text {dom}(f) \cup \text {img}(f), f contains no (non-trivial) cycles for V when viewed as a permutation.

We propose to only consider a cyclic proof "computationally meaningful" when all cycles satisfy bud freshness and are not label-cyclic. Or rather, only consider a cycle computationally meaningful if it satisfies bud freshness, and treat it as a stuck sub-term otherwise.
A proof is well-cycled if all cycles satisfy bud-freshness and no cycles are label-cyclic.
A cycle C with maps (f , \theta ) is inert for x : \phi when f(x) = x, and all nested cycles are also inert for x : \phi .
Nested cycles are defined as those which have their companion on the path from the companion of C to the bud of C.

Given a cyclic proof \Sigma of \Gamma , x : \phi \vdash \psi , and a cyclic proof \Pi of \Gamma ' \vdash \phi , we define the substitution operation \Sigma [x / \Pi ] as \Sigma where:
x : \phi is removed from all contexts
Weakening instances for x : \phi are removed
All axioms for x : \phi are replaced with \Pi

This substitution is only defined when:
All cycles in \Sigma are inert for x : \phi
All axiom occurences for x : \phi have all proof labels of \Gamma ' in the context
All buds in \Sigma with companions "external" to \Sigma do not have x : \phi in the context
If R = \text {ax}, then we just remove the weakening rule and add the weakened formula to the context of the axiom rule instance.

Given some cycle C' internal to C, with maps (g , \eta ), its copy in the unfolding is given by the maps (g' ,\eta ') where:
\begin {align*} g'(f'(x)) := f'(g(x))\\ \eta '(\theta '(x)) := \theta '(\eta (x)) \end {align*}

Given some cycle C' external to C, with maps (g , \eta ), its copy in the unfolding is given by the maps (g' ,\eta ') where:
\begin {align*} g'(x) := f'(g(x))\\ \eta '(x) := \theta '(\eta (x)) \end {align*}
All new cycles created in an unfolding satisfy bud-freshness.

fr:mainmatter.html:mark: TODO: This holds, proof is on my reMarkable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now we have these definitions we can state the property we want to show: assuming bud freshness, and given a cyclic proof \Sigma of \Gamma , x : \phi \vdash \psi , and a cyclic proof \Pi of \Gamma ' \vdash \phi such that the substitution \Sigma [\Pi / x] is undefined, we can perform some amount of weakening reductions and unfolding such that the substitution \Sigma [x/\Pi ] is defined.

Our strategy to do this:
Unfold until all cycles in \Sigma are inert for x : \phi . This requires the lemmas:
(1a) Unfolding preserves well-cycled-ness.
(1b) Unfolding preserves* inertness of cycles and overlapping cycles.
(3a) For any label y, a non-y-inert cycles with all y-inert overlapping cycles can be unfolded to y-inert cycles.
Propagate weakenings for labels in \Gamma ' up to axioms for x : \phi . This requires the lemmas:
(2a) Weakening propagation preserves well-cycled-ness.
(2b) Weakening propagation preserves inertness, and induces inertness in the weakened label.
(3b) For any variable y, a y-bad cycle with all y-good overlapping cycles can be unfolded into a y-good cycle.
(4) Unfolding preserves goodness of cycles and overlapping cycles.

fr:title.text: Getting Agda to provide termination checker debug info

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Getting Agda to provide termination checker debug info

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
If you compile Agda with the debug flag, then run it with verbosity level set to 40 (i.e. add command line option --verbose={40} or -v={40}) then it will print out:
Call graphs
Call matrices
Final results of termination checking

fr:title.text: Contexts and reduction in natural deduction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Contexts and reduction in natural deduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Pfenning's notes on natural deduction deal with this by using hypotheses labelled with variables, with the axiom and implication introduction rules specifying the variable name of the hypothesis they discharge/introduce. In traditional natural deduction systems, essentially the same approach is taken, but with a "de Bruijn index" approach instead of variable labels. Taking one of these approaches makes it very clear during \Rightarrow -reduction which hypotheses is being "eliminated" from the context.

fr:title.text: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These are mostly inspired by Zwart and Marsden's research into no-go theorems for distributive laws between algebraic theories [zwartmarsden2022].

I've been roughly translating properties of algebraic theories into the language of monad containers (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}), by considering:
Shapes s : S as "terms"
Positions p : P\ s as "free variables in the term s"
\iota as a "generic variable placeholder"
\sigma as a "generalised substitution"
\text {pr} as a "reindexing" of positions after a "substitution" This is not meant to be an exact translation; the idea is to get inspiration for properties of monad containers we might want to consider when proving things about monad container distributive laws.
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) satisfies the singleton property if P\ \iota \cong 1. All cartesian monad containers have this property by definition.

A property of algebraic theories that is used implicitly in [zwartmarsden2022] is commutativity of disjoint substitutions, i.e. given terms s, s_0 and a substitution f where for all y, x 
otin 	ext {var}(f(y)) we always have that: s[s_0/x][f(y) / y 
eq x] = s[f(y) / y 
eq x][s_0/x]

The List monad container \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} satisfies this, which makes sense since it can also be represented by an algebraic theory. This also holds for coproduct, reader (trivially), state, writer, and probably many others!
EDIT: In fact, this holds for all monad containers, and the proof is quite simple (just use associativity of \sigma and "pull the case distinctions through the inner \sigma ").
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) has a constant shape if there exists some s_0 : S where P\ s_0 \cong 0.

Notice that all functions P\ s_0 \to S are equal to \lambda \_ . \iota , since P\ s_0 is propositional and pointed (and therefore contractible). As a consequence of this, we have that: \sigma \ s_0\ f = \sigma \ s_0\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) = s_0

This holds for \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} for example: take n to be any natural number greater than 0, take f := \lambda \_ . 0, and then given some x : \text {Fin}\ n we have \sum _{i = 0}^{n} f^x\ i = 1. Notice that this property holds for all n with non-empty position sets, so \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} actually satisfies a stronger condition (analogous to Zwart and Marsden's S4 [zwartmarsden2022]).
This also holds for state, by taking s = \text {id} and f = \lambda \_ . \text {id}.

Following an idea Stef and I had a couple months ago, I'm going to specialse monad container distributive laws to the case where v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simple examples.

Essentially by adopting v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , all of the position equalities become trivial, and we are just left with shape equalities (with no mention of v). Hopefully it will be easier to prove things in this simpler case!

If we look at the compatible composites (\sigma , \text {pr}) corresponding to distributive laws with v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , we get that:
\begin {align*} p = \pi _2\ (\text {pr}_1\ (q , p))\\ q = \pi _1\ (\text {pr}_2\ (q , p))\\ \end {align*}

Brotherston in [brotherston2005] uses the idea of "folding up" the infinite representation of a cyclic proof to obtain equivalent cyclic proofs in cyclic normal form. The folding process essentially annotates a rule graph (that is a "subtree" of the infinte unfolding) with some cycles.
The notion of root-preserving surjective rule graph homomorphism is used to describe mappings between rule graphs that describe the same infinite proofs.

One problem with this (for our use-case) is that this notion does not consider cycles since they are not part of the rule graph data. Also as far as I can tell, the fact that this kind of homomorphism does not only operate at the level of cyclic tree structure, and deals with strict equality of sequents and rules (call these "tree labels") means that it is not generalisable to systems where cycles may be formed up-to other conditions, e.g. substitution or weakening. The equitable partition approach looks like it would generalise the "equality of tree labels" requirement of the homomorphism nicely.

In our use-case, we care about studying the unfoldings of a cyclic proof that are generated "bottom up", i.e. from an existing cyclic proof to a "larger" unfolding. This is in contrast to the "top down" approach - taking the unique infinite unfolding and folding it up to a smaller, finitely-presented proof in some way.

fr:title.text: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Leigh and Wehr in [leighwehr2023] define unfolding at the level of labelled cyclic trees. By disregarding the tree labels (sequents and rules) their definition also works for cyclic trees.
Their unfolding definition covers the "basic" unfoldings that we have considered i.e. those where you unfold a single cycle, and you link the new bud back to either the old companion or the old bud.

As far as I can tell, this definition does not properly extend the cycle map \beta with cycles created by unfolding, apart from that of the one bud that is being unfolded. There is not just one obvious way to do this, so there is definitely something missing in the definition here: a natural way is for newly created buds to link back to the companions for the buds they are copies of.
I think that this notion of unfolding is the closest to what we want to define.

fr:title.text: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Sprenger and Dam's unfolding algorithm in [sprengerdam2003] was developed to find a tree-dischargeable version of a given cyclic proof.

fr:p.html:mark: TODO: Needs discussing: Intuitively, a tree-dischargeable proof \mathcal P is one where the structural dependency ordering \leq _{\mathcal P} of cycles can be mapped monotonically into a given tree-like partial order \preccurlyeq .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The algorithm operates in the "bottom up" direction, taking an existing (injective) cyclic proof \mathcal {P}_0 and unfolding it iteratively. It also does not refer to the sequents or rules associated with nodes in the cyclic proof, instead operating solely at the level of cyclic trees and keeping track of repeated nodes by tagging them with a copy number. Importantly, the algorithm assumes that an induction order discharging \mathcal {P}_0 is given to deal with how new cycles are defined during unfolding.

fr:title.text: Ideas for cyclic proof theory research

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideas for cyclic proof theory research

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since it seems hard to imbue our cyclic proof system with a well-behaved notion of computation (specifically one that works nicely alongside \forall reductions), maybe a change of perspective is required. We could instead work with a reset proof system analogue of \mu HOL^{ex} and try to add a notion of computation to reset proofs.
I first need to understand reset proof systems to see if they are suitable for tackling this problem.

Things working up to this and related things I would like to try:
Do an "Abstract cyclic proofs" treatment of reset proof systems and try to show that the abstractions are related somehow
Look at a reset proof system version of a simpler proof system, i.e. Viswanathan and Viswanathan's HO fixed-point logic [viswanathanviswanathan2004]
A literature review on reset proof systems (currently I only know about Dominik Wehr's licentiate thesis, but this should link to other papers)
See if the \mu HOL^{ex} trace condition can be represented as an activation algebra. If not, perhaps there is some other class of trace category that encompasses trace conditions like ours?

fr:title.text: Ideas for cycle reduction in HOL^{ex}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideas for cycle reduction in \mu HOL^{ex}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We are (still) working out how we can equip cycles with a notion of reduction or "unfolding". We specifically want the property that we can "unfold" a cycle and then replace a free variable along the cycle with some term without breaking the well-formedness of the cycle: lets call this property A.

We've found a criteria that the substitutions along cycles have to satisfy to allow us to "unfold" them in a way that has property A - that is the requirement that each variable is either substituted by itself or a fresh variable w.r.t. the companion sequent. Call this property P. P(\theta , B, C) := \forall x \in \text {fv}(C) . \theta (x) = x \vee \theta (x) \notin \text {fv}(C) If this holds, then we can "unfold" the cycle just once and the resulting proof has property A. If this doesn't hold, the current idea is to translate the proof to a different one where the cycle in question has property P.
The translation revolves around the idea of replacing \mu -formulae with semantically equivalent ones that interact with the free variables of the sequent in subtle way.

fr:title.text: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
I've been reviewing the literature on distributive laws, specifically those papers that Dan Marsden mentioned, and have found some candidates for methods that we could attempt to adapt to finding monad container distributive laws:
Generalising the "abides" property in [zwartmarsden2022] to monad containers - looks like it would be some funky equation on positions in \sigma shapes.
Manes and Mulry I Theorem 4.3.4 mentions something about distributive laws between commutative monads - this might be adaptable.
"Multiple constants" in [zwartmarsden2022] would correspond to multiple shapes having singleton position sets.
Manes and Mulry use "Kleisli strengths" to show distributive laws, we should see what those are in the case of monad containers.
Here's a compilation of monad container and monad container distributive law examples for reference.

Properties/classes of monad containers:
Cartesian
Finitary
Idempotent
Commutative
Affine

"Specific" monad containers:
Representable
Maybe
Writer
Coproduct
List
State
Reverse State - just a curiosity, only definable in a theory with unrestricted fixed points
Update
TODO: Free

Distributive laws:
Any monad container over a representable one
Coproduct over any monad container
Writer over writer
I was previously using Obsidian for my research diary, but I found it a little heavyweight for what I was using it for: weekly (or fortnightly) notes on what I've been thinking about.
Previous entry, Next entry
I'm compiling some ideas I had in October/November last year about different notions of maps between cyclic trees.

A cyclic tree is a tuple (T , \delta ) of a tree T on X (a finite non-empty prefix-closed subset of X^*) and a partial function \delta : \text {Leaf}(T) \rightharpoonup T. We often call \delta the cycle map.
\text {Leaf}(T) is the set of elements in T which do not occur as a strict prefix of any other element in T. \text {Inner}(T) is the complement of this set with respect to T.

Our goal here is to work out what the correct notion of an "unfolding" of a cyclic tree is, in order to have a notion of unfolding cyclic proofs that is applicable to many different cyclic proof systems.
It is easy enough to define some kind of naive homomorphism for cyclic trees:

A corollary of this definition is that buds are mapped to buds: If b is a bud then there is some c where (b, c) \in \delta , hence (f(b),f(c)) \in \delta ' which makes f(b) a bud. The same argument can be made for companions being mapped to companions.
However these are too strict:

After a bit of thought, you can hopefully convince yourself that you cannot define a cyclic tree homomorphism in either direction here. Either the cycle, prefix or root preservations requirements get in the way. The game becomes tweaking the definition to allow homomorphisms between cyclic trees that "infinitely unfold" into the same tree, and disallow them otherwise.
Unfoldings have already been defined in a few different ways in the cyclic proof theory literature.

Brotherston in [brotherston2005] uses the idea of "folding up" the infinite representation of a cyclic proof to obtain equivalent cyclic proofs in cyclic normal form. The folding process essentially annotates a rule graph (that is a "subtree" of the infinte unfolding) with some cycles.
The notion of root-preserving surjective rule graph homomorphism is used to describe mappings between rule graphs that describe the same infinite proofs.

One problem with this (for our use-case) is that this notion does not consider cycles since they are not part of the rule graph data. Also as far as I can tell, the fact that this kind of homomorphism does not only operate at the level of cyclic tree structure, and deals with strict equality of sequents and rules (call these "tree labels") means that it is not generalisable to systems where cycles may be formed up-to other conditions, e.g. substitution or weakening. The equitable partition approach looks like it would generalise the "equality of tree labels" requirement of the homomorphism nicely.

In our use-case, we care about studying the unfoldings of a cyclic proof that are generated "bottom up", i.e. from an existing cyclic proof to a "larger" unfolding. This is in contrast to the "top down" approach - taking the unique infinite unfolding and folding it up to a smaller, finitely-presented proof in some way.

fr:title.text: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Sprenger and Dam's unfolding algorithm in [sprengerdam2003] was developed to find a tree-dischargeable version of a given cyclic proof.

fr:p.html:mark: TODO: Needs discussing: Intuitively, a tree-dischargeable proof \mathcal P is one where the structural dependency ordering \leq _{\mathcal P} of cycles can be mapped monotonically into a given tree-like partial order \preccurlyeq .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The algorithm operates in the "bottom up" direction, taking an existing (injective) cyclic proof \mathcal {P}_0 and unfolding it iteratively. It also does not refer to the sequents or rules associated with nodes in the cyclic proof, instead operating solely at the level of cyclic trees and keeping track of repeated nodes by tagging them with a copy number. Importantly, the algorithm assumes that an induction order discharging \mathcal {P}_0 is given to deal with how new cycles are defined during unfolding.

fr:title.text: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Leigh and Wehr in [leighwehr2023] define unfolding at the level of labelled cyclic trees. By disregarding the tree labels (sequents and rules) their definition also works for cyclic trees.
Their unfolding definition covers the "basic" unfoldings that we have considered i.e. those where you unfold a single cycle, and you link the new bud back to either the old companion or the old bud.

As far as I can tell, this definition does not properly extend the cycle map \beta with cycles created by unfolding, apart from that of the one bud that is being unfolded. There is not just one obvious way to do this, so there is definitely something missing in the definition here: a natural way is for newly created buds to link back to the companions for the buds they are copies of.
I think that this notion of unfolding is the closest to what we want to define.

We want to encompass all of these notions in a few, easy to intuit set of definitions. To tackle the problem of defining cyclic tree unfolding in a natural way, we first look to graph theory for a general notion of unfolding for graphs, and then lift this notion to cyclic trees by essentially viewing them as special kinds of graph.

A starting point for this investigation is Boldi and Vigna's work on graph fibrations [boldivigna2002]. Fibrations and opfibrations are the directed analogues of graph coverings, which are an existing and well-studied notion of unfolding [courcelle2023] for (undirected) graphs. These are all essentially surjective neighbourhood preserving maps between graphs. For example:
The two graphs on the right are coverings of the one on the left, the covering map indicated by letters (i.e. A is mapped to A, etc.).
To extend these ideas to cyclic trees we need a first need a nice notion of cyclic tree homomorphism.
We can transform a cyclic tree into a rooted multi directed graph by "quotienting by the cycle map". This essentially means that we identify nodes that a connected by a cycle. For example:

The root is coloured red, and the cycles are "collapsed" along their arrows to produce the graph on the right. For a cyclic tree (T, \delta ) we call the graph resulting from this transformation T/_\delta , or the cycle-quotient of T.
We can form an inverse to this map - from (rooted multi directed) graphs to cyclic trees. We do this by calculating the "spanning cyclic tree" of the graph.

fr:title.text: Spanning cyclic tree of a graph

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Spanning cyclic tree of a graph

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These maps together have a nice property: all cyclic trees in the image of \text {SCT} are in cycle normal form, and we can compose these two maps to form a "normalisation" map for cyclic trees: given a cyclic tree (T , \delta ), the cyclic tree \text {SCT}(T/_\delta ) is the cycle normal form of (T , \delta )! We will prove this proposition later, by developing the notion of cyclic tree (op)fibrations and showing that there exists an opfibration from \text {SCT}(T/_\delta ) to (T , \delta ).

fr:ul.fr:li: DONE: Talk about "obvious" notion of cyclic tree homomorphism, explain that it is too strict - we want to be able to consider maps between "unfoldings" of cyclic trees, as well as defining explicitly what an unfolding even is.
DONE: Show how cyclic trees can be considered as particular kinds of multi-graph (by "collapsing" the cycles).

Introduce coverings of graphs, and fibrations and opfibrations of digraphs. Motivate the idea that these can be thought of as "unfoldings". Explain the idea of extending the SCT map to a functor, and seeing how opfibrations define maps between cyclic trees.
Show that this gives a nice notion of cyclic tree unfolding with some examples.
Show that it doesn't encompass "change of companion" transformations, but equitable-partition preserving maps do.

We might be able to relax the surjective requirement of the opfibrations to just a surjection on the set of inner nodes - this could potentially allow for "rolling unfoldings" to be included as an instance of a cyclic tree opfibration.

fr:title.text: Diary: Natural deduction-style unfold rule for -formulae

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Diary: Natural deduction-style unfold rule for \mu -formulae

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Previous entry, Next entry

fr:title.text: Diary: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Diary: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Previous entry, Next entry

fr:title.text: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As mentioned in [ahmanuustalu2013], directed container distributive laws are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions. Further, composition of directed containers via a distributive law is a generalisation of the Zappa-Szép product of two monoids. As mentioned in the paper, you can actually recover the definition of a matching pair by looking at distributive laws between representable directed containers.

fr:title.text: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As it turns out, monad container distributive laws are also a generalisation of matching pairs of monoid actions. This is a bit harder to see than in the directed container case, but as before we can recover the data and equations for a matching pair by specialising the distributive law to a particular type of monad container.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As shown, both of these types of distributive law are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions, each in a slightly different way. For directed containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the shapes", and for monad containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the positions".
Edit (29/01/25): we also get that (monad-comonad) mixed container distributive laws correspond to matching pairs of monoid actions when specialised to a particular pair of containers:

fr:title.text: Monad-comonad container distributive law between writer monad and coreader comonad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad-comonad container distributive law between writer monad and coreader comonad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It should be possible to use this to define some kind of monoid bimodules (bialgebras), given that monad-comonad distributive laws are used in the literature [livernetetal2015] to define a "bi-Eilenberg-Moore" category.
Strangely, comonad-monad container distributive laws seem to break this pattern, and do not give us matching pairs of monoid maps when specialising them to particular containers:

fr:title.text: Comonad-monad container distributive law between coreader comonad and writer monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comonad-monad container distributive law between coreader comonad and writer monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This doesn't seem to correspond to anything that I've heard of, and certainly doesn't look like a matching pair of monoid actions, in particular since the first argument of \alpha is a function.
We should be able to define something that looks like a two sided Kleisli category with this.
Previous entry, Next entry

This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities. 887lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S 	riangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , 	ext {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s 	o A) 	o A, satisfying:  egin {align*} \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a) &= a\ \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ 	ext {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p)) \end {align*} 889lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S 	riangleleft P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \lbrack

egthinspace brack \ t_n) &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack s brack 
egthinspace brack \ t_1\ \dots \ t_n\ \end {align*}
using this presentation, the "associativity" equation becomes trivial. I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \iota brack 
egthinspace brack is not necessarily unary in that case, and \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \sigma \ s\ f brack 
egthinspace brack may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack f(i) brack 
egthinspace brack - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

EDIT (12/12/24): I realised that I was missing the associativity equation for the definition of the algebraic theory for a finitary cartesian monad container, and in the process realised that finitary cartesian monad containers are exactly non-symmetric operads!

To show this, consider (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma ). The set (or type) of operations for each n : \mathbb {N} is given by n \mapsto \sum _{s : S} |\negthinspace | P\ s \cong n |\negthinspace | where \iota is the identity operation, and \sigma is composition. All operations have finite arity by the finitary assumption on the monad container.

That monad containers were generalisations of non-symmetric operads (in this way) was already noticed by Tarmo Uustalu in [uustalu2017], but an explicit construction showing how they can be recovered was not given. Based on the rest of this post, I believe that Tarmo's generalisation of the list monad container in terms of any non-symmetric operad characterises exactly the cartesian monad containers that correspond to algebraic theories.
Previous entry, Next entry

Earlier this week Stef and I were working on the monad container distributive law project. We had a very insightful meeting with Dan Marsden who mentioned (among other things) that we should look for applications for our characterisation. Things to try:
Find characterisations for tighter classes of monad containers (i.e. commutative, affine, relevant) and see if this simplifies the distributive law. We have already characterised distributive laws for cartesian monad containers for example.
Prove more than just mere existence of distributive laws - use the characterisation to find exactly how many there are for a given pair of monad containers.
Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
Find which algebraic theories correspond to container monads, to tie our work to Maaike Zwart and Dan's work on distributive laws for algebraic theories.
